content.description: A steep face climb to the top of a small, free-standing pillar. The climbing isn't very noteworthy (gritty and runout) but the summit is very nice.
content.protection: No bolts but you can places some nuts and sling some knobs.
content.location:
This climb is a bit southwest of the route

29 Palms

.

climbs.name: Quickstone
climbs.fa: Jonny Woodward and Darrel Hensel, January 1988

content.description:
This test piece climbs the high quality slab just left of 29 Palms.

Begin about 30 feet left of 29 Palms by stemming off a pinnacle in the chasm until you can make a committing move to attain a stance on the wall. Continue up the slab past 4 bolts.
content.protection: Pro to 2 inches, including some very thin nuts.

climbs.name: Quarter Moon Crack
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett, Alan Roberts & Sally Moser, November 1982

content.description: A very enjoyable route with crux delicate face moves. It faces northwest, so it's in the shade until late afternoon.
content.location: This is around the corner and approximately 100 feet left of the route 29 Palms

content.description: Start on 29 Palms and from the small ramp traverse right onto 39 Slaps and finish up the arete.

climbs.name: The Outsiders
climbs.fa: Russ Raffa, Paul Trapani, Laura Chaiten, & Iza Trapani, 1983

content.description: This climb ascends an attractive dihedral high on the north end of the Arid Piles. Difficult face climbing gains the first of two bolts. The crux is getting to the second bolt but hard moves continue past the second bolt until a large plate is reached. Easier climbing leads to a mantle protected by small stoppers / brass. Two out of five stars.
content.protection: Quickdraws for two 1/4" bolts and a couple of brass pieces / small stoppers. Small cams and one bolt for an anchor. Adventurous walkoff to the northeast for the descent.

climbs.name: Nice and Steep and Elbow Deep
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, April 1986

content.protection: mostly wide gear, up to 4 inches
content.location: This route lies on a separate formation, north of the northwest end of the rock.  The climb is a deep crack on the north end of the formation.

climbs.name: Napkin of Shame
climbs.fa: Charles Cole, Jim Ducker, Maria Cranor, and Randy Vogel, 1982

content.description: a mediocre, awkward crack climb.  It faces northwest, so it's in the shade until late afternoon
content.location: This is around the corner and approximately 100 feet left of the route 29 Palms.

climbs.name: Mr. Bunny Quits
climbs.fa: Darryl Nakahira, Rob Raker, and Dan Leichtfuss

content.description: Steep strenuous finger jamming on fairly good rock.  It faces east.
content.location: Right across from the route 29 Palms

climbs.name: Hare Today, Gone Tomorrow
climbs.fa: Chris Miller and Dave Sorric, January 1999

content.description:
Climbs the face/arete right of

Mr. Bunny Quits

on slightly crunchy holds. Perhaps worth a spin after doing the other routes on the formation.
content.location:
Just right of

Mr. Bunny Quits

.

content.description: Start from a small boulder on the right side of the base. The climb is an excellent exposed steep face. The 5.10b thin face at the top is runout.
content.location: Southeast of the route 29 Palms, a tall steep block has this route running up its exposed outer edge,  Scramble up a ways from the ground to get to the base of the block.

climbs.name: 99 Moves But a Palm Ain't One

content.description:
Start in the obvious short dihedral beneath 29 Palms (to the right of the flake layback start of 29 Palms). Move up and when the short dihedral disappears, pull around the arete to the right to join 39 Slaps; 2 more bolts lead to the shared anchor. This will need a bit of cleaning and a couple of bolts to make it a reasonable lead.

This is a small variation to another TR link-up called Palms Away. Both variations are better than the original, 39 Slaps.
content.protection: TR only at the moment; it will need bolts for a reasonable lead.
content.location: Start in the obvious dihedral beneath 29 Palms.

content.description: This route is just right of 29 Palms

climbs.name: 29 Palms
climbs.fa: Tony Yaniro, Mike Lechlinski, Vaino Kodas and Alan Nelson, 1981

content.description: Difficult lieback/jam moves reach the very steep left-facing corner with a seam in the middle. Extremely technical and challenging palming and stemming moves go over a bulge to a lower angle section with a finger sized crack. Near the top the climb steepens before the anchors.
content.protection:
#000 C3's, small to medium brass and cams, and one 1" cam for protection.

Bolted anchors (3/8") with rappel rings are at the top.
content.location: This climb is on the northwest face of the Arid Piles formation. Approach from the northeast end and enter the 29 Palms Corridor. Scrambling over boulders within the corridor leads to the base of the route.
